metadata.title: Volatility Forecasting for Options Trading
metadata.description: GARCH models, implied volatility prediction, and volatility trading strategies
sources: Options, Futures, and Other Derivatives - John Hull

chunks.topic: Implied vs Realized Volatility - The Core Concept
chunks.content: Implied Volatility (IV): Market's expectation of future volatility, derived from option prices via Black-Scholes. Realized Volatility (RV): Actual historical volatility calculated from price movements. Key relationship: IV tends to exceed RV on average (volatility risk premium). This is why option selling strategies have positive expected value. Measurement: IV from option chains (VIX for S&P 500). RV calculated as annualized standard deviation of log returns. IV/RV ratio > 1 means options are 'expensive' relative to historical norms.
chunks.key_insight: Sell options when IV/RV > 1.2 (options expensive). Buy options when IV/RV < 0.8 (options cheap). The volatility risk premium is the 'edge' in option selling.
chunks.application: Before selling CSPs, check IV percentile. Sell when IV is high (>50th percentile). Our system should track IV/RV ratio for entry timing.
chunks.embedding_text: implied volatility IV vs realized volatility RV core concept. IV market expectation from option prices Black-Scholes. RV historical standard deviation log returns. IV exceeds RV volatility risk premium. IV/RV ratio greater 1 options expensive. Sell options IV high percentile.

chunks.content: GARCH (Generalized Autoregressive Conditional Heteroskedasticity) models volatility as time-varying process. GARCH(1,1) is most common: σ²(t) = ω + α*ε²(t-1) + β*σ²(t-1). Where: ω = long-run variance weight, α = reaction to recent shock, β = persistence of volatility. Key properties: Volatility clusters (high vol follows high vol), Mean reversion (vol returns to long-run average), Asymmetry captured in EGARCH/GJR-GARCH (bad news increases vol more than good news). Use: Forecast next-day volatility, compare to IV for trading signals.
chunks.key_insight: GARCH predicts realized volatility better than simple historical measures. Compare GARCH forecast to IV to find mispriced options.
chunks.application: Implement GARCH(1,1) to forecast next 30-day RV. If GARCH forecast << IV, sell options (overpriced). If GARCH forecast >> IV, buy options (underpriced).
chunks.python_example:
from arch import arch_model
model = arch_model(returns, vol='Garch', p=1, q=1)
result = model.fit(disp='off')
forecast = result.forecast(horizon=30)
chunks.embedding_text: GARCH generalized autoregressive conditional heteroskedasticity predicting volatility. GARCH(1,1) σ² omega alpha epsilon beta. Volatility clusters mean reversion asymmetry. Forecast next-day volatility compare IV trading signals. GARCH forecast less than IV sell options overpriced.

chunks.topic: VIX Term Structure - Contango and Backwardation
chunks.content: VIX term structure shows implied volatility across different expirations. Contango (normal): Near-term IV < longer-term IV. Market calm, expecting possible future turbulence. Backwardation (inverted): Near-term IV > longer-term IV. Market stressed, expecting volatility to decline. Trading implications: Contango favors selling near-term options (time decay + vol crush). Backwardation favors buying near-term options (cheap relative to fear). Monitor VIX futures curve or VIXMT (mid-term) vs VIX. VIX/VIX3M ratio > 1 = backwardation (fear). VIX/VIX3M ratio < 0.9 = steep contango (complacency).
chunks.key_insight: Sell premium in contango (calm markets), buy protection in backwardation (panicked markets).
chunks.application: Check VIX term structure before entering trades. Our ETF accumulation strategy benefits from buying during backwardation (cheaper shares).
chunks.embedding_text: VIX term structure contango backwardation. Contango near-term IV less than longer-term calm market. Backwardation near-term IV greater stressed market. Contango sell near-term options. Backwardation buy near-term options cheap. VIX VIX3M ratio.

chunks.topic: IV Percentile and IV Rank - Finding Opportunities
chunks.content: IV Percentile: Percentage of days in past year when IV was lower than current. IV Rank: (Current IV - 52wk Low) / (52wk High - 52wk Low). Both measure how 'expensive' options are relative to history. Example: SPY IV Percentile 80% means IV is higher than 80% of past year. Rules of thumb: IV Percentile > 50%: Favor selling strategies (CSP, covered calls). IV Percentile < 30%: Favor buying strategies (long puts/calls, debit spreads). IV Percentile 30-50%: Neutral, smaller positions. TastyTrade research shows selling at high IV rank significantly improves win rates.
chunks.key_insight: High IV = sell premium. Low IV = buy premium or stay on sidelines. IV percentile is the single most important filter for options trades.
chunks.application: Add IV percentile check to our options screening. Only sell CSPs when IV Percentile > 50%. This is a key enhancement to improve win rate.
chunks.embedding_text: IV percentile IV rank finding opportunities. IV Percentile percentage days IV lower than current. IV Rank current minus 52wk low divided by range. IV Percentile greater 50% favor selling strategies. Less than 30% favor buying. TastyTrade high IV rank improves win rates.

chunks.topic: Volatility Smile and Skew - Reading Market Fear
chunks.content: Volatility smile: IV varies by strike price. ATM options often have lower IV than OTM puts and calls. Volatility skew: OTM puts typically have higher IV than OTM calls (put skew). This reflects crash risk premium - investors pay more for downside protection. Measuring skew: Compare 25-delta put IV to 25-delta call IV. Large negative skew = high crash fear (puts expensive). Flat or positive skew = complacency. Trading skew: When skew is steep, selling OTM puts captures high premium. When skew is flat, puts are cheap for hedging.
chunks.key_insight: Steep put skew = fear = good time to sell puts (expensive premium). Flat skew = complacency = good time to buy puts (cheap protection).
chunks.application: Monitor skew before selling CSPs. Steep skew means we collect more premium for same risk. Consider skew in strike selection.
chunks.embedding_text: volatility smile skew reading market fear. IV varies by strike price. OTM puts higher IV than calls put skew crash risk premium. 25-delta put vs call IV. Steep skew high crash fear puts expensive. Sell OTM puts steep skew high premium.

chunks.topic: Event Volatility - Earnings, FOMC, and Macro
chunks.content: Implied volatility spikes around known events: Earnings (stock-specific), FOMC meetings, CPI/NFP releases, elections. Event IV: Options expiring after event have elevated IV. Options expiring before event are unaffected. Post-event vol crush: IV typically drops 30-50% immediately after event. Strategies: Pre-event: Sell premium to capture vol crush (risky if big move). Post-event: Often good entry for new positions as IV normalizes. For index options (SPX), economic calendar drives vol. For stock options, earnings calendar is key.
chunks.key_insight: Don't sell options right before earnings unless sizing for potential big move. Best selling opportunities are right after events when IV crushes.
chunks.application: Check earnings calendar before selling CSPs on individual stocks. For SPY, monitor FOMC and CPI dates. Consider timing entries after events.
chunks.embedding_text: event volatility earnings FOMC macro. IV spikes around known events. Options expiring after event elevated IV. Post-event vol crush IV drops 30-50%. Sell premium capture vol crush. Don't sell right before earnings big move risk.

chunks.content: Simple models ranked by accuracy: (1) EWMA (Exponentially Weighted Moving Average): Recent returns weighted more heavily. Decay factor λ typically 0.94. (2) GARCH(1,1): Captures clustering and mean reversion. Best for daily forecasts. (3) HAR (Heterogeneous Autoregressive): Uses daily, weekly, monthly components. Good for longer horizons. (4) Realized GARCH: Combines high-frequency data with GARCH. Most accurate but complex. For retail traders: EWMA or simple GARCH(1,1) is sufficient. Compare model forecast to IV for trade signals. Libraries: Python 'arch' package has excellent GARCH implementation.
chunks.key_insight: You don't need complex models. Simple GARCH(1,1) beats most sophisticated approaches and is easy to implement.
chunks.application: Implement EWMA or GARCH(1,1) for volatility forecasting. Use 'arch' Python package. Compare to VIX/IV for trade timing.
chunks.python_example:
# EWMA example
import numpy as np
lambda_decay = 0.94
ewma_var = returns.ewm(alpha=1-lambda_decay).var() * 252
ewma_vol = np.sqrt(ewma_var)
chunks.embedding_text: practical volatility forecasting models EWMA GARCH HAR. EWMA exponentially weighted decay factor 0.94. GARCH(1,1) clustering mean reversion daily forecasts. HAR daily weekly monthly longer horizons. Simple GARCH beats sophisticated approaches. Python arch package.

chunks.content: Long volatility (expect vol increase): Buy straddles/strangles, buy VIX calls, long gamma positions. Short volatility (expect vol decrease): Sell straddles/strangles, iron condors, sell CSPs. Volatility arbitrage: Trade IV vs RV divergence. Mean reversion: Sell when IV >> RV, buy when IV << RV. Key insight: Most retail traders are natural vol sellers (covered calls, CSPs). This is correct - volatility risk premium favors sellers. But know when to step aside: avoid selling in low IV environments (VIX < 12).
chunks.key_insight: Be a volatility seller most of the time (CSPs, covered calls), but don't sell when IV is already low. Wait for elevated IV.
chunks.application: Our system should be selective: only sell options when IV percentile > 50%. During low vol periods, focus on ETF accumulation instead.
